data.title: Syllabus to Weekly Planner
data.one_liner: A lightweight web app that converts course syllabi into personalized weekly study plans and tracks progress offline.
target_users: College students juggling multiple courses
Students who want structured weekly study plans
Self-directed learners on campus
assumptions: Users have access to course syllabi in digital format (text or PDF) and can input or paste key dates and topics
Users want a simple, repeatable weekly plan with daily tasks aligned to deadlines and topics
No backend is required for MVP; all data can be stored in the browser (localStorage) or in-memory
Users will interact with a basic calendar-like weekly view and progress indicators
There is no requirement for authentication in the MVP
Syllabi can be parsed or manually mapped to weeks by the user in a lightweight way
success_metrics: Demoable MVP achieves participation from at least 3 independent user tests or pilot users within 2 weeks
Average time to generate a weekly plan from a syllabus is under 5 minutes
At least 70% of planned weekly tasks are marked as completed after 2 weeks
User satisfaction score of 4/5 in feedback sessions
No external dependencies or backend services required for MVP

prd.title: Syllabus to Weekly Planner
prd.problem: College students often struggle to translate diverse course syllabi into actionable, weekly study plans. MVP constraints (offline usage, no backend, and no authentication) require a lightweight, browser-based solution that can convert syllabus content into a repeatable weekly plan while tracking progress locally.
target_users: College students juggling multiple courses
Students who want structured weekly study plans
Self-directed learners on campus
goals: Convert course syllabi into structured weekly study plans with tasks aligned to topics and deadlines
Support offline operation by storing all data in the browser (localStorage) without a backend
Provide both automatic syllabus-to-week mapping and lightweight manual mapping when automatic parsing is insufficient
Offer a calendar-like weekly view with progress indicators to track completion
Deliver a demoable MVP within 2 weeks with no external integrations
non_goals: Backend services, authentication, or user accounts
External integrations (calendars, to-do apps, or cloud storage) in MVP
Advanced natural language processing or full PDF parsing beyond lightweight mapping
Cross-device data sync or multi-user collaboration
Mobile-first native app implementation (web app only for MVP)
user_stories: As a student, I want to paste or type a syllabus into the app and automatically generate a week-by-week plan so I can start planning quickly.
As a student, I want to manually map syllabus topics to weeks when automatic parsing isn't possible, so I can still create a usable plan.
As a student, I want a calendar-like weekly view showing days and assigned tasks, so I can see my workload at a glance.
As a student, I want to add, edit, delete, and reorder daily tasks within each week, so I can customize my plan.
As a student, I want to mark tasks as completed and see progress indicators, so I can track my study progress.
As a student, I want all data to be stored locally in the browser so I can use the app offline and without an account.
As a student, I want to reset or clear data, so I can start fresh for a new syllabus.
As a student, I want a simple progress dashboard showing completed vs planned tasks and weekly completion trends, so I can monitor my performance.
functional_requirements: Provide a text input area where users can paste or type syllabus content (text or lightweight structured data) and optionally specify key dates and topics
Support automatic mapping of syllabus content to weeks when structured markers are detected, and a lightweight manual mapping UI when automatic mapping is insufficient
Generate a weekly plan with weeks and days, displaying tasks aligned to topics and deadlines derived from the mapping
Allow CRUD operations on tasks (create, edit, delete) and reordering within each day
Enable marking of tasks as completed and compute per-week and overall progress percentages
Persist all project data in browser localStorage with a simple versioned schema and graceful handling of storage limits or resets
Provide a responsive, calendar-like weekly view with navigation between weeks and clear visualization of tasks per day
Offer controls to reset/clear all data for a fresh syllabus
nonfunctional_requirements: Offline-first: the app operates entirely in the browser without a backend
Performance: generating a plan from a typical syllabus should complete within a few seconds on common devices
Accessibility: keyboard navigable, screen-reader friendly, and with adequate color contrast
Compatibility: works in modern browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Edge) on desktop and mobile, with responsive layout
Data privacy and security: no network requests or authentication; data remains in localStorage unless user exports it
Reliability: robust error handling for malformed input and clear user-facing error messages
risks: User friction during manual mapping when automatic parsing fails
LocalStorage data loss if users clear browser data or use private/incognito mode
Inaccurate syllabus-to-week mapping causing misaligned study plans
Limited MVP scope may hinder perceived usefulness or adoption
Performance or UI complexity if syllabi are very large or highly structured
open_questions: Should the MVP support multiple syllabi per user or just a single active syllabus at a time?
Would exporting the plan to JSON or ICS (calendar) format be valued in the MVP, or should this be deferred?
How should weeks start (e.g., Monday vs Sunday) and how to handle courses with irregular deadlines across weeks?
What level of automated parsing is acceptable, and how should manual mapping be facilitated to minimize effort?
Is there a need for basic localization or language support beyond English in the MVP?

data.title: Syllabus-to-Weekly Plan Planner
data.one_liner: A lightweight web app that converts course syllabi into personalized weekly study plans and tracks progress across the semester.
target_users: College students (undergraduates) seeking structured study plans
Students juggling multiple courses who need a weekly roadmap
assumptions: Syllabi are accessible in text form or can be pasted into the app
Users have a list of courses and weekly time availability to map tasks
Local storage or lightweight local database is acceptable for MVP data persistence
Users value weekly progress tracking but do not require calendar integrations in v1
success_metrics: Demoable MVP delivered within 2 weeks
Number of users who generate at least one weekly plan per course in a session
Average time to generate a weekly plan from a syllabus
User satisfaction rating (0-5) after first use
Retention: percentage of users who return to edit/view plans within a week
Qualitative feedback from local demos on usability and usefulness

prd.title: Syllabus-to-Weekly Plan Planner
prd.problem: Students struggle to convert course syllabi into actionable weekly study plans. They need a lightweight, MVP-grade web app that can accept syllabus text, produce per-course weekly plans aligned to their available study hours, and track progress locally without external integrations.
target_users: College students (undergraduates) seeking structured study plans
Students juggling multiple courses who need a weekly roadmap
goals: Convert syllabus text into weekly, course-specific study plans
Allow users to define weekly availability per course and generate feasible plans
Provide a simple, browsable view of weekly tasks per course across the semester
Track progress locally (task completion) and display completion metrics
Deliver a demoable MVP within 2 weeks that runs entirely in the browser
Avoid any external integrations or server dependencies in v1
Persist user data locally (in-browser) between sessions
non_goals: Calendar integrations (Google/ICS) or external syncing
Server-side hosting or multi-user authentication
Advanced analytics or predictive scheduling beyond simple hour-based allocation
LMS integrations, assignment submission tracking, or grade calculations
Mobile app edition or iOS/Android-native features
user_stories: As a student, I want to paste a syllabus text for a course so the app can extract topics and create a plan scaffold.
As a student, I want to add multiple courses with names and their total weeks, so I can plan across a semester.
As a student, I want to specify my weekly study hours per course, so tasks are allocated to realistic time blocks.
As a student, I want the app to generate a week-by-week plan for each course based on topics and available hours.
As a student, I want to view a dashboard that shows weekly tasks for each course in a single glance.
As a student, I want to mark tasks as completed and see progress percentages to stay motivated.
As a student, I want to edit or reallocate tasks when my schedule changes, without losing data.
As a student, I want to export or print my current weekly plan for offline reference.
As a student, I want my data saved locally so it persists across browser sessions.
functional_requirements: Allow per-course setup: course name, number of weeks, and optional syllabus text input
Accept syllabus text input for each course and perform lightweight parsing to extract topics or modules
Provide a planning engine that assigns topics to weeks based on user-entered weekly hours and a simple rule set
Offer an editable weekly view where users can adjust tasks, estimated hours, and week assignment
Provide progress tracking: mark tasks complete, calculate completion rate per course and overall
Implement local data persistence using browser storage (localStorage or equivalent) with data schema for courses, weeks, tasks, and progress
Present an overview dashboard and per-course weekly breakdown views in a responsive UI
Support data export (JSON or printable text) and data import for restoration
Operate entirely client-side with no external network requests or integrations
nonfunctional_requirements: Performance: initial plan generation should complete within a few seconds on a modern browser
Reliability: works offline and persists data across sessions without server interaction
Usability: simple, clean UI with intuitive onboarding and minimal learning curve
Accessibility: keyboard-navigable controls and proper ARIA labels; color contrasts for readability
Compatibility: supported in major desktop browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge) with responsive layout
Security/Privacy: no data leaves the user’s device; clearly communicate local storage usage
risks: Syllabus parsing accuracy: heterogeneity of syllabus formats may hinder automatic topic extraction
Scope creep: risk of adding features beyond MVP (calendar sync, LMS integration)
Performance with large syllabi or long-term plans could degrade if not optimized
User adoption: students may prefer existing tools or require a more guided experience
Data loss risk if localStorage capacity is exceeded or users clear data unintentionally
open_questions: What is the minimum viable syllabus parsing approach (manual mapping vs. auto-extraction) and how will users correct parsing errors?
How many weeks should the MVP assume by default, and how should it handle non-standard semester lengths (14 vs 15 weeks)?
What rules will the planning engine use to allocate topics to weeks (e.g., even distribution, priority-based, or time-block based)?
Should the export format include a human-readable printable view, or only machine-friendly JSON, or both?
How will the UI scale when handling 2-4 courses simultaneously, and is a per-course toggle preferred for initial MVP?
What accessibility and localization considerations should be included from the start (labels, date formats, etc.)?

data.title: Syllabus to Weekly Planner
data.one_liner: A lightweight web app that turns course syllabi into personalized weekly study plans and tracks progress, designed for solo development and quick local demos.
target_users: College students juggling multiple courses
Students seeking structured, trackable study plans

assumptions: Users have access to one or more syllabi (PDF/HTML/text) that can be copied into the app
Students want a simple, predictable weekly plan rather than advanced scheduling
No external authentication is needed for MVP; local storage is acceptable

Users will manually input or paste course topics and due dates
success_metrics: Time to generate a weekly plan per course (target < 60 seconds for MVP)
Number of courses users can manage in a single plan (target 3-5 in MVP)

Demoability: successful local demo with 2-3 syllabi
Satisfaction: NPS or Likert satisfaction score after trial

prd.title: Syllabus to Weekly Planner
prd.problem: Students need a lightweight tool to convert varied course syllabi into concrete, week-by-week study plans. Existing approaches are manual, error-prone, or rely on heavy tooling. The MVP should be a small, local web app that accepts syllabus input (paste or manual entry), generates a personalized weekly plan for each course, and tracks simple progress without external services.
target_users: College students juggling multiple courses
Students seeking structured, trackable study plans
First-year and transfer students adjusting to college workload
goals: Convert syllabi into personalized weekly study plans for multiple courses
Support both pasted syllabus content and manual entry of modules, topics, and due dates
Provide a simple progress-tracking system for completed topics across courses
Operate entirely locally in the browser for offline demos and MVP simplicity
Be MVP-ready for a quick 2-week demo with 2–3 syllabi and no external integrations
non_goals: Automatic PDF parsing or OCR of syllabi
Calendar integrations or reminders
Multi-user authentication or cloud sync
AI-assisted planning or advanced optimization
Server-based features or external services in v1
user_stories: As a student, I want to paste syllabus text into the app to automatically create course topics and weeks so I can generate a plan quickly.
As a student, I want to manually create a course with a number of weeks and add topics for each week.
As a student, I want to assign topics to specific weeks and specify due dates, so I have a clear weekly plan.
As a student, I want to view a weekly plan for a single course, showing topics by week and deadlines.
As a student, I want to view a dashboard that shows progress across all my courses in one place.
As a student, I want to mark topics as completed and see updated progress.
As a student, I want to edit, reorder, or move topics and weeks when my schedule changes.
As a student, I want all data to be stored locally in my browser, so I can demo offline.
As a student, I want to export or print a summary of my weekly plan for a course.
functional_requirements: Create, edit, and delete courses with a course name, number of weeks, and a default weekly structure
Define weeks for each course and provide the ability to add, remove, or rename weeks
Add topics with titles, optional due dates, and optional notes; assign topics to specific weeks
Support paste-and-fill from syllabus text (plain text or bullet lists) to populate topics and weeks, with manual adjustments allowed
Generate and display a weekly plan per course, showing topics organized by week and their due dates
Mark topics as completed and track progress per course and overall across all courses
Persist all data locally in the browser (localStorage) with automatic save on changes and on reload
Provide an export/import mechanism (JSON) for plan data and a printable summary suitable for sharing or printing
Offer a dashboard view aggregating progress, upcoming deadlines, and course status
nonfunctional_requirements: Local-first design: all data stored in browser; no server calls for MVP
Performance: generating a weekly plan per course should complete within a reasonable time (target under 60 seconds for MVP with typical data sizes)
Usability: simple, minimal UI with clear affordances; keyboard accessible and responsive across devices
Reliability: data persists across page reloads and browser sessions within localStorage limits
Compatibility: works in modern desktop and mobile browsers with graceful degradation in older environments
risks: User input friction: manual entry may be time-consuming for complex syllabi, risking low adoption
No automatic parsing of PDFs or rich syllabus formats, which could limit usefulness for some users
LocalStorage limits and privacy modes could cause data loss or restrict usage in some environments
Demoability constraints: ensuring a smooth local demo across devices may be challenging if browsers differ in storage availability
Future extensibility: scaffolding for features like calendar sync or authentication may require refactoring
open_questions: How should weeks be defined: fixed ahead of time vs. dynamic/adaptive based on topics?
What is the minimal viable data model for courses, weeks, and topics to support MVP use cases?
Should there be a default start date to anchor weeks, and how should due dates align with calendar weeks?
What export format is most useful for users: JSON for re-import, or a printable summary/PDF-compatible format?
What is the simplest UX flow for onboarding new users and entering their first syllabus quickly?

milestones.title: Milestones for Syllabus to Weekly Planner MVP

milestones.name: Foundation: Core data model and MVP scaffolding
milestones.objective: Establish the local app skeleton, data models for Course/Week/Topic, and localStorage persistence; create a minimal UI scaffold to navigate basics.
deliverables: Project scaffold with index.html, main JS, and CSS
In-code data model definitions for Course, Week, and Topic
LocalStorage persistence layer with automatic save on changes
Basic in-app navigation to view and switch courses
Seed data to illustrate MVP workflow (2-3 example courses)

milestones.name: Course and Week/Topic CRUD
milestones.objective: Implement creation, editing, deletion of courses; define weeks per course; add/edit/delete topics; assign topics to weeks; basic input validation.
deliverables: UI for creating, editing, deleting courses with number of weeks
Week management: add/remove/rename weeks per course
Topic management: add/edit/delete topics with titles, due dates, notes; assign to weeks
Validation and basic error handling
Persist changes to localStorage

milestones.name: Weekly Planning and Progress Tracking
milestones.objective: Generate weekly plans per course, display topics grouped by week with due dates; mark topics as completed; show progress dashboards per course and across all courses; support data export/import JSON.
deliverables: Weekly view: topics organized by week with due dates
Completion marking and per-course progress tracking
Global progress dashboard across all courses
Export/Import JSON for plan data

milestones.name: Syllabus Paste-Fill and UX Enhancements
milestones.objective: Add paste-and-fill from syllabus text to populate topics/weeks; provide preview and adjust flow; improve accessibility and responsiveness; autosave.
deliverables: Syllabus paste parser to generate weeks and topics (basic plain-text/bullet list support)
Paste area with live-preview mapping to weeks/topics and ability to adjust
UI accessibility improvements and responsive layout
Autosave changes to localStorage

milestones.name: Demo Readiness and Polish
milestones.objective: Finalize demo-ready MVP with sample syllabi for 2–3 courses, printable summaries, onboarding, and performance refinements; ensure offline stability.
deliverables: 2–3 ready-to-demo sample syllabi seeded in app
Printable/summary export for sharing
Onboarding guidance and lightweight help
Performance optimizations and final bug fixes

data.title: Syllabus to Weekly Study Planner
data.one_liner: A local web app that converts college syllabi into personalized weekly study plans and progress tracking, designed for solo development and demoable offline in v1.
target_users: Undergraduate college students
Students juggling multiple courses
Self-motivated learners who prefer structured plans
assumptions: Users have digital or well-structured syllabi available for import or copy-paste.
Users want to break syllabus content into weekly tasks with due dates and estimated effort.
An offline-first web app (running in the browser with local storage) is acceptable for v1.
Minimal or no collaboration features are required in v1.
Users are comfortable exporting or viewing their plan locally without requiring a server.
success_metrics: Time to generate a 4-week plan from a syllabus: under 5 minutes for 90% of test users.
Plan adherence: ≥70% of planned tasks marked as completed each week.
User retention: at least 60% of beta users returning for a second week of use.
Satisfaction: average rating ≥ 4.0/5 in beta feedback.
Import/creation rate: at least 3 syllabi/import sessions per user within the first week of use.

prd.title: Syllabus to Weekly Study Planner
prd.problem: Many college syllabi are inconsistent in format and terminology, making it hard for students to translate requirements into actionable weekly tasks. Existing tools require manual planning, are often online-only, and do not meet the MVP constraint of being a demoable, offline-first local web app for a solo developer.
target_users: Undergraduate college students
Students juggling multiple courses
Self-motivated learners who prefer structured plans
goals: Convert syllabus content into a structured weekly study plan with tasks, due dates, and estimated effort.
Operate offline-first with data stored locally in the browser (no server required).
Provide a clear weekly overview and progress tracking for adherence.
Enable quick MVP generation (default 4 weeks) with the ability to adjust weeks and re-generate.
Support local export/print options for offline use and sharing.
non_goals: Real-time collaboration or multi-user features
Cloud sync or LMS integrations in v1
Advanced analytics or learning insights beyond basic completion metrics
Complex PDF/image syllabus parsing or OCR in v1
Mobile app native experiences or push notifications
user_stories: As a student, I want to paste or paste/upload a syllabus text and have the app create a structured plan, so I don't have to manually interpret the syllabus.
As a student, I want the app to distribute tasks across weeks by default (4 weeks) with due dates, so I have a ready plan.
As a student, I want to see a weekly overview with tasks, due dates, and estimated hours, so I can plan my study time.
As a student, I want to mark tasks as completed and see progress, so I can stay motivated.
As a student, I want to adjust the number of weeks and re-generate the plan, so I can tailor to my schedule.
As a student, I want to customize tasks by editing titles, due dates, and estimated effort, so the plan matches my needs.
As a student, I want to save plans locally and reopen them later without internet, so I can continue offline.
As a student, I want to export the plan as JSON/Markdown/printable view, so I can share or print.
As a student, I want a simple, clean UI that works on desktop and mobile, so I can use it anywhere.
functional_requirements: Import: Support copy-paste or file upload of plain-text syllabus; parse into a structured syllabus object.
Plan generation: Generate a weekly plan by distributing syllabus items across weeks (default 4 weeks); allow user to set number of weeks and regenerate.
Task management: Create, edit, and delete tasks; mark tasks as completed; track per-week and overall progress.
Editing capabilities: Allow editing of task titles, due dates, and estimated effort; adjust week allocations manually if needed.
Local storage: Persist syllabus, tasks, and progress to browser storage (localStorage or IndexedDB) with autosave.
Export/print: Provide options to export the plan as JSON, Markdown, or a printable view; support offline viewing.
UI/UX: Present a weekly view with clear task lists, progress indicators, and responsive design for desktop and mobile.
Reset: Provide a clear data reset option to start over from the initial state.
nonfunctional_requirements: Offline-first: All data remains stored and operable entirely in the browser with no server interactions.
Performance: Generate a 4-week plan from typical syllabi within 2 seconds on standard hardware; scale gracefully with up to ~100 tasks.
Accessibility: Keyboard navigable, proper semantic structure, and adequate color contrast to meet WCAG 2.1 AA baseline.
Cross-browser compatibility: Works on modern Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge without relying on vendor-specific APIs.
Security and privacy: No data is sent to external services; user data is stored locally and never transmitted by default.
Usability: Minimal onboarding, clear success metrics, and intuitive controls to reduce setup time.
risks: Ambiguity in syllabus formatting may lead to incorrect automatic task extraction or misalignment of weeks.
LocalStorage quota limits or browser storage clears can result in data loss for users with large syllabi.
Performance degradation with unusually long or complex syllabi or very large task sets.
Users may expect features (e.g., calendar integrations) that are outside v1 scope, causing misaligned expectations.
If parsing relies on heuristic text extraction, edge cases could require manual correction, affecting MVP appeal.
open_questions: What is the minimum viable default parsing rule set for common syllabus formats, and should we define a supported template to reduce ambiguity?
How should we handle estimation of effort for tasks when the syllabus does not specify hours per week?
Should the app automatically accommodate holidays or term breaks when distributing tasks across weeks?
Is there value in supporting additional import formats (e.g., CSV or Markdown syllabus templates) in v1 or should we limit to plain text?
What is the preferred export format for sharing with others (JSON, Markdown, or printable PDF) given MVP constraints?
